title: What is the area of the small pentagon formed by the inscribed 5 pointed star inside the larger pentagon of side length a? In terms of a? - Quora

response.answer_text: If the black outer pentagon has side length a, then the internal pentagon has side length [math]\frac{a}{\phi^2}[/math] where [math]\phi = \frac{1+\sqrt{5}}{2} = 1.618033989…[/math] aka Ye Olde Golden Ratio. Since [math]\phi^2[/math] is the same as [math]\phi[/math] + 1, then the length of the outer is 2.618033989… times the inner. Consider the two shaded triangles in the figure below. The gold triangle is a 36–36–108 isosceles triangle, and in such a triangle, the ratio [math]\frac{a}{b}[/math] will be [math]\phi[/math] since cos36° = [math]\frac{\phi}{2}[/math]. The blue triangle is a 36–72–72 isosceles, and in such a triangle, the ratio [math]\frac{b}{c}[/math] will also be [math]\phi[/math] since sin18° = [math]\frac{\phi-1}{2}[/math]. Thus the ratio [math]\frac{a}{c}[/math] will be [math]\frac{a}{b} \frac{b}{c} = \phi^2.[/math]  You had also asked about the areas of the figures. The area of a regular pentagon as a function of its side length a isn’t anything pretty: [math]A=\frac{a^2\sqrt{5(2+\sqrt{5})}}{4}[/math]. Since the pentagons’ sides are in proportion [math]\phi^2[/math], their areas will be in proportion [math]\phi^4[/math]. The area of the interior pentagon, as a function of the exterior side, will be [math]A'=\frac{a^2\sqrt{5(2+\sqrt{5})}}{4\phi^4}[/math].

The side length of the larger pentagon is [math]a[/math]. Let the side lengths [math]s[/math] and [math]a_2[/math] be marked as follows:  There’s enough information on the diagram to enable you to show why the marked angles are [math]36 °[/math] and [math]72 °[/math] exactly. So let’s dig in! Using sine-rule, we can write [math]s[/math] in terms of [math]a[/math] as follows: [math]\begin{align}s=a\dfrac{\sin(36 °)}{\sin(108 °)}=a\dfrac{\sqrt{\dfrac{5}{8}-\dfrac{\sqrt{5}}{8}}}{\sqrt{\dfrac{5}{8}+\dfrac{\sqrt{5}}{8}}}=\dfrac{a}{2}(\sqrt{5}-1)\tag*{}\end{align}[/math] Now we can use cosine-rule in the triangle with sides [math]a,a[/math] and [math](s+a_2+s)[/math]and angle of [math]108 °[/math] as follows: [math](2s+a_2)^2=a^2+a^2-2(a)(a)\cos(108 °)\tag*{}[/math] [math]\implies 2s+a_2=a(\sqrt{2-2\cos(108 ° )})\tag*{}[/math] [math]\displaystyle =a\sqrt{2-2\left(\dfrac{1}{4}-\dfrac{\sqrt{5}}{4}\right)}\tag*{}[/math] [math]=\dfrac{a}{2}(\sqrt{5}+1)\tag*{}[/math] [math][=a\varphi][/math] Now, [math]a_2=(2s+a_2)-2s[/math] [math]\implies \displaystyle a_2=a \left(\dfrac{\sqrt{5}+1}{2}-(\sqrt{5}-1)\right)\tag*{}[/math] [math]=\dfrac{a}{2}(3-\sqrt{5})\tag*{}[/math] The formula for area of a regular pentagon of side length [math]a[/math] is [math]\dfrac{a^2}{4}\sqrt{5(5+2\sqrt{5})}\tag*{}[/math] So the area of the smaller pentagon is: [math]\displaystyle \dfrac{\left(\dfrac{a}{2}(3-\sqrt{5})\right)^2}{4}\sqrt{5(5+2\sqrt{5})}\tag*{}[/math] [math]=\dfrac{a^2}{4}\sqrt{\dfrac{5}{2}(25-11\sqrt{5})}\tag*{}[/math] [math]=\dfrac{a^2}{8}\sqrt{250-110\sqrt{5}}\tag*{}[/math]
